fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of an unknown man, watercolour on vellum by Thomas Flatman, 1663-1665.
fields.physical_description: Portrait of a young man, turned slightly to right, looking to front and wearing a neckcloth tied with a black ribbon; a landscape in the right background. Features in long free hatches of brown and sanguine with some blue-grey, blue and black highlights in the eyes, on a pale creamy carnation ground; hair in long strokes of brown over a pale brown wash with some paler brown opaque heightening; cravat in a thick white wash, modelled with grey-brown over a pale brown wash; coat in brown wash, hatched in opaque grey for the lights and shaded in darker brown; background a sky and landscape, hatched and stippled in greys, blues, greens, with white and ochre; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Frame: Nineteenth-century electro-gilt imitation of the standard seventeenth-century type; the convex back overlapping the sides, which have a deep channel and rise to a plain bezel, which holds the flat glass by its bevelled edge; the hanger of tear-drop form and D-section, channelled down the middle and bifurcating as flat wire into two short reverse turns and diminishing spirals of four turns. A scratched inscription on the back: 1083-/ £16-/ £100 0-/ [illegible] Hr duke of Glocester /J Hoskins.
fields.title: Unknown Man
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Cat.123, p.217. Full Citation: “123 Unknown Man 1663-5 FA 688 Oval 61 x50mm Features in long free hatches of brown and sanguine with some blue-grey, blue and black highlights in the eyes, on a pale creamy carnation ground; hair in long strokes of brown over a pale brown wash with some paler brown opaque heightening; cravat in a thick white wash, modelled with grey-brown over a pale brown wash; coat in brown wash, hatched in opaque grey for the lights and shaded in darker brown; background a sky and landscape, hatched and stippled in greys, blues, greens, with white and ochre; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: Rubbed, engrimed, marginal losses; faded; retouched at the edges and a scratch to the left; the retouches darkened. Signed: Not signed. Inscribed in impressed metal-point, erased, on the back: Norwich to. Frame: Nineteenth-century electro-gilt imitation of the standard seventeenth-century type; the convex back overlapping the sides, which have a deep channel and rise to a plain bezel, which holds the flat glass by its bevelled edge; the hanger of tear-drop form and D-section, channelled down the middle and bifurcating as flat wire into two short reverse turns and diminishing spirals of four turns. A scratched inscription on the back: 1083-/ £16-/ £100 0-/ [illegible] Hr duke of Glocester /J Hoskins. Provenance: A Mr Whitehead (probably Jeffery Whitehead, the collector, subsequently a member of the Burlington Fine Arts Club), from whom purchased, 1866 (£26). Literature: Foster 1903, vol. Il, p. 31 (a 'flat' example of Cooper);Williamson 1904, vol. I, p. 72, pl. XLIII, no. 2 (as Cooper); Catalogue of Miniatures, 1908, p. 8, fig. 13 (as Henry, Duke of Gloucester by Cooper); Foster 1908, p. 314 (as Cooper); Long 1930, p. 13 (‘ascription doubtful'); Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 21 (as 'formerly ascribed to' Flatman). Despite the apparent certainty of the entry in the Catalogue of Miniatures, 1908, this miniature was often omitted from the early literature, though probably only accidentally by Foster from his otherwise undiscriminating lists of 1914-16. In a MS note, probably of the early 1920s, Long wrote:, 'I doubt if this miniature is by Cooper, fine though it is. The background and costume recall in treatment a miniature by or attributed to Hoskins in the Duke of Buccleuch's Collection.' (1) Whether Long meant to attribute this miniature to Hoskins is doubtful, but certainly his comparison of it with the so-called Maynard was apt; both in style and in the likeness of the sitter, there is a resemblance. But for the Maynard iconography, see Cat. No. 119. It was Reynolds who took the final step: 'In my view this is a very good work by Flatman', (2) an attribution that has not been questioned. The phrase 'formerly ascribed to Flatman' in Summary Catalogue, 1981 was a redundant hangover from the miniature's previous placing as a Cooper. The identification as Henry, Duke of Gloucester, although given in the Catalogue of Miniatures, 1908, was never accepted by the Museum. Prince Henry (1639/40-1660) was the third son of Charles I and seems to have resembled his brothers strongly, particularly the Duke of York. Of the accepted images of Prince Henry, the closest in date to this miniature are by.Pieter Thyssens at Knole House, in Kent, and a Lely studio picture of him in Garter robes at Euston Hall. 1 I.e., Sir John Maynard. Kennedy 1917, pl. xxxii, there attributed to Samuel Cooper, but probably by Flatman. 2 MS note, March 1949.”
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> A Mr Whitehead (probably Jeffery Whitehead, the collector, subsequently a member of the Burlington Fine Arts Club), from whom purchased, 1866 (£26).
